definition: building/shop/term for certain service establishments/embassy or consulate/schoolroom (old)/CL:家[jia1]

sentences.english: The government closed down the newspaper.
He works as a journalist on a local paper.
sentences.chinese: 他在一家当地报馆担任记者。

sentences.english: Steve intended to go to the local newspaper .
sentences.chinese: 史蒂夫打算到当地报馆去。

sentences.english: The minister's speech was sent to the newspaper in advance.
sentences.chinese: 部长的讲话稿事先就送到了报馆了。

sentences.english: The tsarist government closed down the newspaper in December 1905.
sentences.chinese: 沙皇政府在1905年12月查封了这家报馆。

sentences.english: If we go to the papers they might hurt Ann or do something to her baby.
sentences.chinese: 要是我们告诉报馆，他们会伤害安或者她的孩子。

sentences.english: When he was a young man, he went to a newspaper office in Kansas City where he was living.
sentences.chinese: 年轻的时候，他去过他曾居住在堪萨斯城的一家报馆。

sentences.english: I'm working on the local sheet. Won't you give me a statement ?
sentences.chinese: 我在本地那家报馆工作，你不给我发表一篇谈话吗？

sentences.english: Charlie, I want you to let me work on the Chicago paper.
sentences.chinese: 查利，我希望你让我去芝加哥的报馆工作。

sentences.english: I think I'd go down to that newspaper office right now and ask her.
sentences.chinese: 我想我该马上去一下那儿的报馆问问她。

definition: Dagong Bao, popular newspaper name/Ta Kung Pao, newspaper founded 1902 in Beijing, now published in Hong Kong
Shao Piaoping (1884-1926), pioneer of journalism and founder of newspaper Beijing Press 京報|京报, executed in 1926 by warlord Zhang Zuolin 張作霖|张作霖
(old) police station in a foreign concession 租界[zu1 jie4]
to run a newspaper/to publish a newspaper
foreign concession, an enclave occupied by a foreign power (in China in the 19th and 20th centuries)
Zou Taofen (1895-1944), journalist, political theorist and publisher
